mn9:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn9:1.3: There Venerable Sāriputta addressed the bhikkhus:
mn9:2.1: “Friends, they speak of this thing called ‘right view’.
mn9:2.2: To what extent is a noble disciple one of right and straight view, who is endowed with absolute confidence in the Dhamma, and has come to the true Dhamma?”
mn9:2.3: “Friend, we would travel a long way to learn the meaning of this statement in the presence of Venerable Sāriputta.
mn9:2.4: May Venerable Sāriputta himself please clarify the meaning of this.
mn9:2.5: The bhikkhus will listen and remember it.”
mn9:2.6: “Well then, friends, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
mn9:3.1: “A noble disciple understands the detrimental and its root, and the beneficial and its root.
mn9:3.2: To this extent a noble disciple is one of right and straight view, who has absolute confidence in the Dhamma, and has come to the true Dhamma.
mn9:4.1: But what is the detrimental and what is its root? And what is the beneficial and what is its root?
mn9:4.2: Killing living creatures, taking what is not given, and sexual misconduct; speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or frivolous; longing, ill will, and wrong view.
mn9:5.1: And what is the root of the detrimental?
mn9:5.3: This is called the root of the detrimental.
mn9:6.2: Abstaining from killing living creatures, taking what is not given, and sexual misconduct; avoiding speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or frivolous; non-longing, non-ill-will, and right view.
mn9:7.1: And what is the root of the beneficial?
mn9:7.3: This is called the root of the beneficial.
mn9:8.1: When a noble disciple understands in this way the detrimental and its root, and the beneficial and its root, and has completely given up the underlying tendency to passion, gotten rid of the underlying tendency to resistance, eradicated the underlying tendency to the view and conceit ‘I am’, given up ignorance and given rise to knowledge, they make an end of suffering right in the present experience.
mn9:8.2: To this extent too, a noble disciple is one of right and straight view, who has absolute confidence in the Dhamma, and has come to the true Dhamma.
mn9:9.1: Saying “Good, friend,” those bhikkhus delighted in and expressed appreciation for what Venerable Sāriputta said. Then they asked another question:
mn9:9.2: “But friend, might there be another explanation for how a noble disciple is one of right and straight view, who has absolute confidence in the Dhamma, and has come to the true Dhamma?”
mn9:10.2: A noble disciple understands nutriment, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.
mn9:10.3: To this extent too, a noble disciple is one of right and straight view, who has absolute confidence in the Dhamma, and has come to the true Dhamma.”
mn9:11.1: But what is nutriment? What is its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation?
mn9:11.2: There are these four nutriments. They maintain beings that have been born and help those that seek to be born.
mn9:11.4: Solid food, whether coarse or fine; pressure is the second, mental intention the third, and consciousness the fourth.
mn9:11.5: Nutriment comes with craving. Nutriment ceases when craving ceases. The practice that leads to the cessation of nutriment is simply this Noble Eightfold Path, that is:
mn9:11.6: right view, right intention, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right recollection, and right composure.
mn9:12.1: When a noble disciple understands in this way nutriment, the origin of nutriment, the cessation of nutriment, and the practice that leads to its cessation, and has completely given up the underlying tendency to passion, gotten rid of the underlying tendency to resistance, eradicated the underlying tendency to the view and conceit ‘I am’, and given up ignorance and given rise to knowledge, they make an end of suffering right in the present experience.
mn9:12.2: To this extent too, a noble disciple is one of right and straight view, who has absolute confidence in the Dhamma, and has come to the true Dhamma.”
mn9:13.1: Saying “Good, friend,” those bhikkhus … asked another question:
mn9:13.2: “But friend, might there be another explanation for how a noble disciple is one of right and straight view … ?”
mn9:14.2: A noble disciple understands suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.
mn9:14.3: To this extent too, a noble disciple is one of right view … and has come to the true Dhamma.
mn9:15.1: But what is suffering? What is its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation?
mn9:15.2: Birth is suffering; aging is suffering; death is suffering; sorrow, lamentation, displeasure, sadness, and distress are suffering; association with the disliked is suffering; separation from the liked is suffering; not getting what you wish for is suffering. In brief, the five-assumption-aggregates are suffering.
mn9:16.1: And what is the origin of suffering?
mn9:16.2: It’s the craving that leads to renewed being, accompanied by delight-and-passion, which delights wherever it lands. That is,
mn9:16.3: craving for sensuality, craving for being, and craving for non-being.
mn9:16.4: This is called the origin of suffering.
mn9:17.1: And what is the cessation of suffering?
mn9:17.2: It’s the fading and cessation of that very same craving without remainder; giving it up, letting it go, releasing it, and not resting upon it.
mn9:17.3: This is called the cessation of suffering.
mn9:18.1: And what is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering?
mn9:18.2: It is simply this Noble Eightfold Path, that is:
mn9:18.4: This is called the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
mn9:19.1: When a noble disciple understands in this way suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to its cessation, and has completely given up the underlying tendency to passion, gotten rid of the underlying tendency to resistance, eradicated the underlying tendency to the view and conceit ‘I am’, and given up ignorance and given rise to knowledge, they make an end of suffering right in the present experience.
mn9:19.2: To this extent too, a noble disciple is one of right and straight view, who has absolute confidence in the Dhamma, and has come to the true Dhamma.”
mn9:20.1: Saying “Good, friend,” those bhikkhus … asked another question:
mn9:20.2: “But friend, might there be another explanation for how a noble disciple is one of right and straight view … ?”
mn9:21.2: A noble disciple understands aging and death, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation …
mn9:22.1: But what are aging and death? What is their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation?
mn9:22.2: The aging, decrepitude, broken teeth, gray hair, wrinkly skin, diminished vitality, and failing faculties of the various beings in the various orders of beings.
mn9:22.5: The passing away, perishing, disintegration, demise, mortality, death, decease, breaking up of the aggregates, laying to rest of the corpse, and cutting off of the life faculty of the various beings in the various orders of beings.
mn9:22.7: Such is aging, and such is death.
mn9:22.8: This is called aging and death.
mn9:22.9: Aging and death come with birth. Aging and death cease when birth ceases. The practice that leads to the cessation of aging and death is simply this Noble Eightfold Path …”
mn9:24.2: “But friend, might there be another explanation for how a noble disciple is one of right and straight view … ?”
mn9:25.2: A noble disciple understands birth, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation …
mn9:26.1: But what is birth? What is its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation?
mn9:26.2: The birth, inception, conception, production, manifestation of the aggregates, and acquisition of the sense fields of the various beings in the various orders of beings.
mn9:26.4: Birth comes with being. Birth ceases when being ceases. The practice that leads to the cessation of birth is simply this Noble Eightfold Path …”
mn9:28.2: “But friend, might there be another explanation for how a noble disciple is one of right and straight view … ?”
mn9:29.2: A noble disciple understands being, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.
mn9:30.1: But what is being? What is its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation?
mn9:30.2: “There are these three states of existence.
mn9:30.3: Sensual being, material being, and immaterial being.
mn9:30.4: Being comes with assumption. Being ceases when assumption ceases. The practice that leads to the cessation of being is simply this Noble Eightfold Path …”
mn9:32.2: “But friend, might there be another explanation for how a noble disciple is one of right and straight view … ?”
mn9:33.2: A noble disciple understands assumption, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation …
mn9:34.1: But what is assumption? What is its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation?
mn9:34.3: The assumption of sensuality, the assumption of views, the assumption of virtue-and-duty, and the assumption of of a view of self.
mn9:34.4: Assumption comes with craving. Assumption ceases when craving ceases. The practice that leads to the cessation of assumption is simply this Noble Eightfold Path …”
mn9:36.2: “But friend, might there be another explanation for how a noble disciple is one of right and straight view … ?”
mn9:37.2: A noble disciple understands craving, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation …
mn9:38.1: But what is craving? What is its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation?
mn9:38.2: There are these six classes of craving.
mn9:38.3: Craving for forms, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and phenomena.
mn9:38.4: The practice that leads to the cessation of choices is simply this Noble Eightfold Path …
mn9:40.2: “But friend, might there be another explanation for how a noble disciple is one of right and straight view … ?”
mn9:41.2: A noble disciple understands feeling, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation …
mn9:42.1: But what is feeling? What is its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation?
mn9:42.2: There are these six classes of feeling.
mn9:42.3: Feeling born of pressure through the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mental faculty.
mn9:42.4: Feeling comes with pressure. Feeling ceases when pressure ceases. The practice that leads to the cessation of feeling is simply this Noble Eightfold Path …”
mn9:44.2: “But friend, might there be another explanation for how a noble disciple is one of right and straight view … ?”
mn9:45.2: A noble disciple understands pressure, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation …
mn9:46.1: But what is pressure? What is its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation?
mn9:46.2: There are these six classes of pressure.
mn9:46.3: Pressure through the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mental faculty.
mn9:46.4: Pressure comes with the six sense fields. Pressure ceases when the six sense fields cease. The practice that leads to the cessation of pressure is simply this Noble Eightfold Path …”
mn9:48.2: “But friend, might there be another explanation for how a noble disciple is one of right and straight view … ?”
mn9:49.2: A noble disciple understands the six sense fields, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation …
mn9:50.1: But what are the six sense fields? What is their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation?
mn9:50.2: There are these six sense fields.
mn9:50.3: The sense fields of the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mental faculty.
mn9:50.4: The six sense fields come with name-and-form. The six sense fields cease when name-and-form ceases. The practice that leads to the cessation of the six sense fields is simply this Noble Eightfold Path …”
mn9:52.2: “But friend, might there be another explanation for how a noble disciple is one of right and straight view … ?”
mn9:53.2: A noble disciple understands name-and-form, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation …
mn9:54.1: But what is name-and-form? What is its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation?
mn9:54.2: Feeling, perception, intention, pressure, and attention—
mn9:54.4: The four primary elements, and form derived from the four primary elements—
mn9:54.6: Such is name and such is form.
mn9:54.8: Name-and-form comes with consciousness. Name-and-form ceases when consciousness ceases. The practice that leads to the cessation of name-and-form is simply this Noble Eightfold Path …”
mn9:56.2: “But friend, might there be another explanation for how a noble disciple is one of right and straight view … ?”
mn9:57.2: A noble disciple understands consciousness, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation …
mn9:58.1: But what is consciousness? What is its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation?
mn9:58.2: There are these six classes of consciousness.
mn9:58.3: Eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mental faculty consciousness.
mn9:58.4: Consciousness comes with activities. Consciousness ceases when activities cease. The practice that leads to the cessation of consciousness is simply this Noble Eightfold Path …”
mn9:60.2: “But friend, might there be another explanation for how a noble disciple is one of right and straight view … ?”
mn9:61.2: A noble disciple understands activities, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation …
mn9:62.1: But what are activities? What is their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation?
mn9:62.2: There are these three kinds of activities.
mn9:62.3: The bodily activity, the verbal activity, and the mind-activity.
mn9:62.4: Activities come with ignorance. Activities cease when ignorance ceases. The practice that leads to the cessation of activities is simply this Noble Eightfold Path …”
mn9:64.2: “But friend, might there be another explanation for how a noble disciple is one of right and straight view …?”
mn9:65.1: A noble disciple understands ignorance, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation …
mn9:65.3: But what is ignorance? What is its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation?
mn9:65.4: Not knowing suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
mn9:66.1: Ignorance comes with influxes. Ignorance ceases when influxes cease. The practice that leads to the cessation of ignorance is simply this Noble Eightfold Path …”
mn9:68.1: Saying “Good, friend,” those bhikkhus delighted in and expressed appreciation for what Venerable Sāriputta said. Then they asked another question:
mn9:68.2: “But friend, might there be another explanation for how a noble disciple is one of right and straight view … who has right view, whose view is correct, who has absolute confidence in the Dhamma, and has come to the true Dhamma?”
mn9:69.2: A noble disciple understands influx, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.
mn9:69.3: To this extent too, a noble disciple is one of right and straight view, who has absolute confidence in the Dhamma, and has come to the true Dhamma.”
mn9:70.1: But what is influx? What is its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation?
mn9:70.3: The influx of sensuality, the influx of being, and the influx of ignorance.
mn9:70.4: Influx comes with ignorance. Influx ceases when ignorance ceases. The practice that leads to the cessation of influx is simply this Noble Eightfold Path, that is:
mn9:70.5: right view, right intention, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right recollection, and right composure.
mn9:71.1: When a noble disciple understands in this way influx, the origin of influx, the cessation of influx, and the practice that leads to its cessation, and has completely given up the underlying tendency to passion, gotten rid of the underlying tendency to resistance, eradicated the underlying tendency to the view and conceit ‘I am’, and given up ignorance and given rise to knowledge, they make an end of suffering right in the present experience.
mn9:71.2: To this extent too, a noble disciple is one of right and straight view, who has absolute confidence in the Dhamma, and has come to the true Dhamma.”
mn9:71.3: This is what Venerable Sāriputta said.
mn9:71.4: Pleased, the bhikkhus delighted in what Venerable Sāriputta said.
